Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCE Institutional Transformation Award: NDSU ADVANCE FORWARD - Transforming a Gendered Institution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Dakota State University is a land-grant institution that, since 1999 and under the leadership of President Joseph Chapman, has undergone tremendous growth in student enrollment (over 12,500 total students, a 2-fold increase in graduate students, and a 3-fold increase in international students), doctoral programs (41), and research expenditures (over $100 million/year). Despite these significant successes, our progress in diversity has been modest and has not yet reached the level needed to meet President Chapman's goal of becoming "globally recognized as a contemporary metropolitan land-grant university." This ADVANCE FORWARD proposal marshals energies and resources to meet this important challenge. NDSU will set in place a formally recognized structure, the Commission on the Status of Women Faculty, headed by the Provost and linked to key administrative authority, with strategies that reach across the university to achieve institutional climate change and advance women, particularly in the STEM disciplines. The FORWARD team will implement these transformational efforts with a three-prong focus:
1. Campus Climate: Our goal is to create a respectful and supportive environment that fosters women's success. We will create new policies and practices through our Commission on the Status of Women and will add an assistant in the Office for Equity and Diversity to strengthen recruitment. We will provide incentives in the form of grants to encourage research on gender and will hire consultants to help departments address gender issues. Additionally, the program will set up workshops and training for groups of administrators and faculty, including deans, chairs/heads, faculty, and male allies.
2. Advancement and Leadership: Our aim is to ensure that women faculty, through mentoring and professional development, receive the knowledge, skills, support, and resources needed for successful teaching, research, and leadership. The program establishes and supports mid-career and cohort mentoring groups, and offers grants for course release, grant-writing support, leadership training, and individual travel.
3. Research: Our goal is to discover if, how, and why our programs work to transform the University. Throughout the project, we will examine our processes and evaluate the reasons for their relative effectiveness. We will disseminate our results broadly through workshops at other universities, professional conferences, and refereed publications.

Intellectual Merit: This project will contribute knowledge and understanding of how to stimulate, implement, and sustain institutional change that leads to a more diverse institution, evidenced by 1) increased women faculty; 2) increased women competitive researchers; 3) increased women in leadership positions; and 4) an overall environment that permits women to flourish. Our research to uncover the processes that link women's performance to organizational factors will contribute to an understanding of how gendered institutional cultures and structures may be changed to facilitate the achievement of women faculty's full potential.

Broader Impact: ADVANCE FORWARD programs for institutional transformation will be merged with broader NDSU diversity efforts to create a more inclusive campus community, including people of color and people with disabilities. We will develop programs, conduct research, and widely disseminate information so that similar campuses can emulate our successes. Our results will provide templates for peer institutions with similar issues on recruitment, retention, and advancement of women faculty. We fully expect that the methods proposed and the outcomes described in the evaluation program will aid other institutions to tap into the full faculty potential by developing positive environments in which women researchers can excel. Most importantly, as a result of this grant, women faculty at NDSU will contribute to the scientific and technical knowledge base of the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The North Dakota State University Advance FORWARD: Transforming a Gendered Institution project developed and implemented a comprehensive, research-driven strategy to increase participation of women in all Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) faculty and academic administrative positions. FORWARD sought a pervasive transformation to alter the culture of the institution by changing underlying assumptions, and institutional behaviors and processes affecting the whole institution. Such transformation required multiple interventions and the engagement of faculty, staff, and administrators – both women and men - as facilitators and leaders. Specifically, FORWARD worked to improve the climate across campus, enhance recruitment efforts, increase retention and advancement, and expand leadership opportunities.

Initiatives implemented to improve the campus climate included:

  • A male faculty Advocates & Allies program.
  • Gender training and research opportunities.
  • The creation of Commission on the Status of Women Faculty and Women Faculty with Disabilities Task Force. 

Initiatives implemented to enhance recruitment of women faculty by employing targeted recruitment strategies included:

  • Creation of a position to assist with efforts to generate more diverse applicant pools.
  • Training sessions and materials for search committees.

Initiatives implemented to increase retention and advancement of women faculty included:

  • Mentoring programs for midcareer and junior faculty.
  • Course release grant opportunities.
  • Revision of promotion/tenure policies and practices and student ratings of instruction for their impact on inclusiveness outcomes. 
  • The formation of a Promotion to Professor Task Force.

 Initiatives to open leadership opportunities by promoting and hiring women into academic leadership positions included:

  • Annual offering of leadership development training and discussion series.
  • Implementation of a policy change to require posting of part-time and interim administrative opportunities.

 FORWARD organized over 160 presentations and workshops: More than 90% of faculty participated in at least one event (97% of women and 88% of men). Further, FORWARD developed institutional programs, strategies, practices, and policies for the full participation and advancement of women in STEM that can be adopted and adapted more widely. FORWARD-developed materials are available via the FORWARD website (www.ndsu.edu/forward).

Summary of Major Outcomes:

(1)   Expanded the number of women in 17 of the 22 STEM departments; 20 have at least one woman in their departments. Forty of the total 42 departments have at least one woman faculty. Several STEM departments are among those with the highest percentage of women faculty nationally.   

(2)   Increased the number of STEM women faculty from 44 to 78 (16% to 24%); increased the number of STEM women full professors from 4 to 12 (7% to 17% in all fields); STEM chairs from 1 to 3 (3 to 9 in all fields); deans from 1 to 2; and provost/viceprovosts/presidents from 2 to 5.

(3)   Improved research productivity of women faculty, directly supporting over 120 principal investigators to obtain more than $4.58M in funding.

(4)   Developed the nationally known Advocates& Allies program, which has engaged men in institutional transformation and helped NDSU to develop vocabulary for discussing campus climate, gender issues, and unconscious bias. Trained over 250 NDSU men as allies (64% of faculty men) with 83% reporting that they would be able to implement new strategies to promote a more equitable climate for women faculty. Provided training to more than 100 men at four other institutions.

(5)   Created guidelines and hosted over 35 workshops for faculty search and tenure evaluation committees. Faculty report feeling that they are better able to address unconscious bias (95% agree) and gender inequity during the search process (94% agree); identify and recruit a diverse pool of candidate (91% agree); and implement new strategies to address unconscious bias during the promotion and tenure evaluation process (83% agree).

(6)   Helped women faculty acquire new skills, information or understanding about successfully managing their academic career (85% agree) and balancing work and life commitments (100% agree); and influenced positively their comfort level with the promotion and/or tenure process (90% agree).

(7)   Designed and implemented high impact policies and practices to level the playing field for women faculty; new and enhanced policies include modified duties, disability accommodation, tenure clock extension, internal search requirements and dual career hiring.

(8)   Enhanced the campus climate; faculty feel that their knowledge about how to promote a positive climate at the institution has increased (91% agree) and they would be able to implement new strategies to promote a more positive climate (86% agree). Influenced positively women faculty’s experience of the campus climate (92% agree) and decision to remain at NDSU (95% agree).

(9)   Created organizational structure through the Office of the Provost and Commission on the Status of Women Faculty to reinforce and support institutional transformation for equity.

 “FORWARD team has accomplished a lot in a short period of time, and they have done so in a campus environment in which women faculty have been severely underrepresented at every level. Essentially, the original plan of the grant has now been fully implemented.” External Evaluation Report, 2014.
